greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number with exactly n representations as a sum of five positive squares or 0 if no such number exists (cf. A025429).
comment: It seems as if 33 is the largest number with no such representation. 60 seems to be the largest one with exactly one representation.
More generally, see A080673 for the largest number with n such representations. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 04 2016
link: Hagen von Eitzen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..78107
example: a(4) = 62 because there are exactly four representations as a sum of 5 squares: 62 = 1+4+4+4+49 = 1+4+16+16+25 = 4+4+4+25+25 = 4+4+9+9+36.
mathematica: f[k_] := f[k] = Length[Select[PowersRepresentations[k, 5, 2], #[[1]] > 0 &]]; a[n_] := (k = 1; While[f[k++] != n]; k-1); Array[a, 54] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 26 2011 *)
f[n_] := f[n] = Block[{c = Range@ Sqrt@ n^2}, Length@ IntegerPartitions[n, {5}, c]]; t = Array[f, 50000, 0]; Table[ Position[t, n, 1, 1], {n, 190}] - 1 (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 01 2014 *)
results.author: _Rainer Rosenthal_, Mar 01 2003
ext: Definition adjusted to cope with otherwise undefined values and b-file extended by _Hagen von Eitzen_, Jun 05 2014
